ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a great understanding of our government and how politics work in our country
I learned not only about the American Political system but also a lot about the theories and practices that fuel it.
An understanding of major theories in the study of American politics.
Knowledge of the American political system and how it has evolved over time, and the logic behind the patterns we see in modern-day politics
lots of the inner workings of American Politics. holistic class
STAN CHRISTINA KINANE. PERIOD.
I learned about politics in the US and how the political system worked.
Deeper understanding of American politics
Great course that offered detailed learning about the US Federal government and the electorate.

Introduction to American political system (i.e. three branches of government, elections and campaigning, etc.). It's a bit different from AP US Government because it definitely takes a political science approach to a lot of the topics we discuss

I gained a great baseline knowledge of the US political system along with learning how to read political science studies and research. The majority of the course revolves around explaining the checks and balances of the various branches of government, tying this into the political theory of collective action problems.

Learned so much about political theory as well as how American politics is all about solving collective action problems. Really expanded on previous knowledge of American government through learning theory.

You learn the foundations of American political science both in terms of the legal aspect (constitution, federalism, civil rights, and civil liberties), institutions (three branches), and external sources of politics (voting, parties, elections, media, and interest groups). You know what you're getting into- it is a course that deals with breadth. Please be aware that it is not for everyone (people, for instance, with lots of political knowledge or who took AP Gov), but it can be very interesting for people of any major!!
I gained great overview to the many topics surrounding the United States political landscape.
I learned how to read political science papers and analyze them.

I learned almost absolutely nothing in the lectures. Oh, yesin the lectures there had been some interesting facts about the bureaucracy that I didn't know. Everything else came from the readings, which were one mind-numbingly boring social science study after another. If I have to read another pseudo-scientific study on legislators' strategic interactions with the president and interest groups, I'm going to vomit. Take a game theory class instead.
Question American politics - deeply analyze complex text
Being able to analyze the US political climate through different theories
Basic knowledge of political science and American government.
A better understanding of the American political system.
I learned more about Americas political institutions (Congress, executive branch, judiciary, Bureaucracy) and other aspects of political participation (such as voting and protesting).
This is truly an excellent course. I learned how to read political science studies, discuss in a political science course, write essays, and basic American politics knowledge.
I developed a good foundational understanding of how our government is structured.
I gained a valuable knowledge about American politics.
Basic intros to political science.
I learned the American systems of government, the forces that change and influence it, and how to interpret ways of thinking about it. Generally I learned some basic political philosophy as well
I discovered a new interest in political science I never knew I had.
A good introduction to American politics and the forces that affect it. The political science literature read is a good foundation for studies going forward.

I learned about the branches of American government, current topics in American politics, and various influences on the American political system such as interest groups, the media, and public opinion. In addition, I learned valuable writing skills and an ability to assess political science research articles.
Knowledge regarding theories that explain issues of Congress, basic history regarding American political institutions, info around non traditional branches of gov't.

This course taught me how to view American Politics at a baseline and fundamental level starting with the constitution and then working our way up to the modern state of affairs with the separation of powers.
I learned about the American political system and the ways in which each branch interacts with one another.
I learned a lot about American government and politics.
I learned the foundational history and structure of American politics. I engaged with historical and analytical text and learned to synthesis them.
Developed a great understanding of the US and how this government came to be and functions now.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: strengths: she follows her slides and the class is very well organzied

Honestly, this class is very strong in general, I think more randomization of the quizzes will hold students more accountable to come to class, but Professor Kinane also understands how students work and makes it clear that fostering learning is the priority.

Learning about the political science theories was interesting, but sometimes the course felt like a refresher of content that many of us had already learned in high school U.S. history and government classes.

Strengths: Very engaging lectures and readings, ability to drop two reading quizzes if necessary

Weaknesses: Sometimes an unfeasible amount of reading was given for the week, but this didn't happen very often

strengths: very fair class (put in the work and get rewarded), covered a lot of topics that all related to each other nicely, really dug into each topic and each topics relevance was clear by the end of the discussion, final exam set-up was very fair and mitigated a lot of anxiety while still allowing students to really feel as though they've learned the material (my studying/preparation allowed me to see my knowledge come together and fill in any gaps I had)

weaknesses: section probably not necessary for this course
I think this course is set up very nicely and the material is very manageable. It can feel a lot like AP Gov in the beginning of the class, but it gets better towards the end.
ICON CHRISTINA KINANE. FLAWLESS. QUEEN. AMAZING.

The main strength for me were sections, which I found always engaging. Lectures were sometimes boring, we were assigned an obnoxious amount of readings every week that we sometimes never went over or mentioned. The format of the exams is a bit odd.
Teacher was amazing!

Strengths: lectures were pretty well done and content was communicated very well. the course load was not bad at all and grading was very lenient. It's pretty gutty.
Weakness: sometimes the material felt repetitive and hard to engage in since it's stuff we have talked about in history/social science classes for most of our lives (assuming you're American). if you're an international student who is unfamiliar with the American political system then maybe you would gain a lot from this course

Strengths: This course is well organized. The lectures are all super interesting. Kinane is an amazing lecturer. Overall, there are so many strengths of this course!
Weaknesses: There is a LOT of reading, often more than one can realistically complete. I think it would be helpful if the reading was only given in excerpts or if it would be decreased. Also, there are a lot of differences in the TA sections, as some TAs discussed readings while others discussed the material from the lecture.

Strengths- It was a very interesting course (even though it is foundational) and the professor is truly incredible! The quizzes were really fine and all you have to do is skim each reading for the main idea and a few of its important aspects). The lectures were engaging and the final was kind because you knew all of the questions and were basically encouraged/motivated to engage with the material. Most of all, I loved the professors' energy and enthusiasm! The professor cared about our success.

Weaknesses- Every section was handled differently and I did not appreciate that more people got material reviews than others (who simply read outside readings that had little to do with the substantive content of the class and what we were tested on for midterms/final). I would have appreciated better review sessions (both for the section and before the midterm) in which we went over what we had covered in the past week. 
There was no feedback on the essay and little help at all from the TFs. That was disappointing.
No feedback on the midterm either. All we learned was the grade.
It was hard to improve.

No weaknesses I can think of. The overall scope of the course was amazing. The professor was phenomenal and showed so much commitment to teaching the material, and the teaching assistant was on top of his game.
Weakness: lectures are extremely repetitive, slower learning environment than some of my high school classes.

Strengths: It's a gut. You'd enjoy it if you like reading social science papers without thinking too deeply about them.
Weaknesses: Terrible lecturer who treated students like elementary-age childrenI will die happy if I never hear the phrase "you are budding political scientists" ever again. I fell asleep in 80% of the lectures, and my masochistic self attended every one of them, unlike a full two-thirds of the class. We are encouraged to do the bare minimum, by which I mean skip the textbook entirely and skim the papers in the ten minutes before class. The ridiculous weekly reading quizzes did not motivate genuine engagement with the course. Final exam answers were given out beforehand like candy. The paper was an exercise in futility and sections were a joke that falls flat and no one laughs. This entire semester, not a single student was challenged to think about a single interesting question, and we did little else besides parroting findings from random research papers.
The course is impeccable and covers a wide range of topics. I believe the course can evolve and actually talk more about slavery and its repercussions on American politics

Strengths: Having laid back quizzes and assignments
Weaknesses: Having in-person exams as opposed to more paper assignments
The quizzes were great commitment mechanisms and the readings were not overwhelming.
The largest strength was the professor. Very charismatic and straight forward,
Kind of a boring class overall. Professor of super nice though and accommodating of your needs.

I appreciated that I always knew the expectations for the class and doing the readings and having engagement correlated directly with doing well. However, I wish that our final exam had been a take home essay, because I think I would have done better work that way.

This professor was very engaging and you can see she is passionate about what she teaches. Also, the pop quizzes arent as scary as they may seem when you see them on the syllabus if that worries you at all (usually they are one or two questions and just based on the weeks reading, and we got a heads up a few days before, which I very much appreciated.) We also had an open-book final, which I also appreciated.
This is truly an excellent course. Its very well organized I just wish we got back feedback on our essays and exams.
I felt that the lectures were very engaging. I just wished that the readings were more evenly spread out and lectures were posted.
I thought the course was great.
Strength is the practicality of the course.

The strengths of this course are the ground that it covers, not only do we learn about formal systems, but we learn about the political landscape as a whole when we study media and public opinion. If you think about it, they could be their own classes separate from the three branches of government and the constitution. It sets a prospective American Government student up really well. The kinds of readings is another strength, not only to we analyze theory, but we look at social science and political science research. The only weakness was the speed at which we covered everything (one lecture per topic) and the amount of reading associated with each topic. Not in that the amount of reading was too much, but given the time frame to master each topic, it felt like a lot.
Honestly, isn't much I would change. It is structured to force students to study but rewards effort with the grade.

Strengths include the breadth of topics covered, the quiz commitment mechanism encouraging students to do the readings, and Professor Kinanes incredible teaching style. Some weaknesses are that the lectures recaps can feel repetitive, the pop quizzes can be stressful, and section can be boring when other students havent done all the readings. The course might be improved by skipping content recaps to instead go over the content in more depth the first time around and increasing the number of quizzes but providing warnings for when all quizzes will take place/what readings they will be on. Alternatively, keep the current quiz framework but encourage section leaders to cold call more so that the few students who have done the readings arent the only ones talking.
Tying course to current issues in the US would be a great idea. :)
This course was extremely helpful because of an enthusiasm surrounding it in lecture and in readings which made me think harder and more diligently about politics in a way I hadnt before.

The course is nicely set up and the professor does a wonderful job of preparing students for the exams!

One weakness of the course is that the lecture slides can begin to feel a bit repetitive throughout the semester.

Strengths: lecture is engaging and informative and the discussion sections are very insightful
Weakness: I cant think of one
The course was very easy to understand and remain engage.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. I would recommend this class to anyone that wants a good intro class and is interested in american politics

Yes, I would. It helps you develop a really cool and in-depth understanding of our political system: how voters think, how politicians think, why people make decisions how they do. This class made me more excited about my political science major; I was always happy to be an active participant in section.
Yes, if you are planning on majoring in political science it is a good intro course that introduces you to important theories in political science.

I would highly recommend this course to any student with even a remote interest in American politics. This course not only pushed me to pursue a political science double major, but also taught me how to thoroughly understand the modern-day political scene I observe today.
Yes. It's a great intro class for people who might want to explore political science as a major or just simply get their feet wet.
Yes! A good introduction to poli sci and will offer you with the basic information you need.
Yes, it really is a good intro to American politics. They cover a lot of information but the assignments and grading are both super fair. Would recommend to someone of any major.
YES FOR CHRISTINA.
No, unless you are a political science major (or any adjacent major).
Yes I would! Amazing class!

Yes if you need it for a pre-requisite (EP&E or political science). If you want a gut then this is also a pretty good one. If you are actually interested in political science then I'm sure there are better courses offered that have more interesting info.
Especially as an international student, this course proved useful to introduce a survey of US politics. However, I wouldn't take this course if you're a junior or senior.
Yes! Kinane is such a fun lecturer, and this really expanded my knowledge of how American politics works.

Yes, I would recommend it overall. I really enjoyed the content and the professor and I feel better prepared to take more advanced political science courses. I believe people from any major can benefit from this course. However, only take it if you are interested. I would not call it a real gut simply because of the reading load. Also section isn't that great. Take it for Kinane and for the substantive content! And the relatively fair assignments.

Yes. Take this class regardless of how much you care about politics. The material is relevant to everyone, and the material is taught from a non biased lens. Professor Kinane is awesome and is understanding of the stresses of student life, and adjusts the class to allow everyone to succeed. As long as you care you will do will in the class.
Yes.

I absolutely do not recommend this class to any serious student of American politics. It's an absolute waste of time. Lectures are a farce, you don't need to go to them. If you want to debate the pros and cons of, for example, dynamic/rigid Supreme Court interpretations, then take a class focused on the topic and do not go to section, where we rehash the same tired concept over and over for 50 minutes and then call it quits. Writing the paper will not teach you to think about a topic any more deeplyit's more of an exercise in how well you can regurgitate and cite the social science papers the class read on the topic. It is close to the worst class I've taken at Yale. At least it was easy.
Yes its an informative and essential xourse
Yes as it introduces very well how the US government works and offers very informative readings
Yes. It was a great foundational course for political science. I would recommend it as one of the intro courses majors must take.
Yes, this class was very fun and informing.
Yes, if has little knowledge of United States government.

I would recommend this class if you want to know more about how politics in America works! I took this after PLSC 116, and I would recommend that others do the same! However, this is not a class on American history, but rather the political system! So keep that in mind.
Yes!
I would recommend this course at it is a very good introduction for individuals who want to explore political science as a major option.
Absolutely.
Yes. Great intro to evasive politics.

Yes! especially a student who took AP US Gov, and couldn't test out of taking PLSC 113. The discussion portion of the class will probably be more fun because you may have the background knowledge solidified, and can explore it in a deeper way in this class. For those who have not taken AP US Gov, (myself) this is also really great because you get a great foundation for interpreting American Politics.
Yes, I learned a lot and enjoyed doing it.

I would take it if you're looking for an introductory political science course or if you want to learn more about how American politics functions. But if you're not interested in the topic at all, the subject matter can be boring.
Absolutely I loved this course. It allowed me to better understand the American Government and the history behind our Nation

I highly recommend taking this course. The Professor tells everyone on the very first day that she wants everyone to succeed and finish with a good grade. Her belief in student success shows in her efforts to engage with students in class and at office hours, continually offering to provide personalized book suggestions and answer any questions. The course content is extremely interesting, and I learned a ton of new information. Its highly relevant to current times and provides useful commentary on our current political atmosphere.
Probably not, unless a student has very little understanding of American politics/history.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student, regardless of major, because I think you take more from it than most other courses at Yale. This course is fundamental for civics and will help those in it get a better grasp of the American political structure around them.

Yes, Professor Kinane is a wonderful lecturer and she is always so enthused about learning and teaching! I would recommend taking this course if one is interested in learning about the American political system and the varying interactions between the branches of government.
I definitely would because the way the course is taught it encourages learning rather than just cramming and trying to get a good grade.
I would recommend this class to anyone who wishes to have a broad introduction to politics in the United States.
Yes, I learned a lot of important information and was excited to learn.
